newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan 1996 M2 growth may not hit 9-14 pct target.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan 1996 M2 growth may not hit 9-14 pct target.

text.p: Taiwan's M2 money supply growth may not fall within the official target of 9-14 percent in 1996, vice central bank governor Hsu Chia-tung said on Tuesday.

"It is possible that the growth may not fall within the target, but we will not aggressively seek to meet the target of nine percent," Hsu told reporters. Taiwan's M2 -- the broadest measure of the island's money supply -- grew 8.44 percent from a year earlier in August after rising 8.47 percent in July. The September figure will be announced on October 25.
Hsu said liquidity in the banking system was loose at present.

"It may affect the stability of consumer prices, so it is not appropriate to further loosen monetary policy," Hsu said, adding that the central bank would conduct open market operations when necessary to mop up excess funds.
The central bank said on Saturday after a board meeting that it would leave Taiwan's monetary policy unchanged.
Central bank officals have noted in recent days that current interbank money rates were low and foreign exchange rates stable, implying Taiwan's monetary policy needed no adjustment.
Bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong said on October 7 that liquidity had become "slightly too loose" but that the bank would maintain an "appropriately loose" monetary policy.
